So to recap;

  • create issue in cucumber/cucumber.
  • PR coding in gherkin-pretty/go as the go get path in cucumber/cucumber.
  • reads AST from pipe/stdin writes to uri.
  • out forces write of file to a specific path.
  • URI with an HTTP URL will fail fast with “I can’t do that Dave” type error.
  • alternatively for HTTP URL would it make sense to have a “workspace” flag and write the feature files to disk stripping the (http|https)://? So “https://cuke.io/alice/features/blah.feature” written to “$WORKSPACE/cuke.io/alice/features/blah.feature”.
natbobc
2018-05-09 09:01:44

@Aslak Hellesøy ^

Aslak Hellesøy

It would be fantastic if you could help out with that @Gem!

#207 New maintainers wanted!
<p>The creator of godog (<a href="https://github.com/l3pp4rd">@l3pp4rd</a>) has stepped down as a maintainer and kindly donated the project to the cucumber GitHub organisation.</p> <p>We're looking for one or more new maintainers. The tasks are roughly:</p> <p>• Code! mpkorstanje
2020-02-29 04:45:34

*Thread Reply:* Jvm prints pickles and then step by step.

lonnblad

lonnblad

mpkorstanje
2020-02-29 05:13:34

*Thread Reply:* What do you mean by context?

mpkorstanje
2020-02-29 05:22:04

*Thread Reply:* Initially jvm wouldn't print the pretty report until the end. This had people wondering if their tests were running or not.

mpkorstanje
2020-02-29 05:22:55

*Thread Reply:* (When running serially it would print immediately)

mpkorstanje
2020-02-29 05:24:12

*Thread Reply:* I have seen no complaints about interleaved printing so I think that was the right choice.

<pre><code>/** The specification for the formatting originated from &lt;https://www.relishapp.com/cucumber/cucumber/docs/formatters/json-output-formatter&gt;. I found that documentation was misleading or out dated. To validate formatting I create a ruby cucumber test harness and ran the same feature files through godog and the ruby cucumber. The docstrings in the cucumber.feature represent the cucumber output for those same feature definitions. lonnblad
2020-03-06 04:36:54

*Thread Reply:* so I believe I have a solution for the issue with installing godog after the migration to gherkin-go v9.2.0 https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/243

if you are running ~go1.11, go1.12 or go1.13~ within the $GOPATH, you would need to install godog like this: GO111MODULE=on go get -v <a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1">github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1</a>

• adding GO111MODULE=on will allow go get and go mod to work together as intended • adding @v0.8.1 will install a specific version instead of master if you are running ~go1.14 or one of the other versions~ outside of the $GOPATH, they should add @v0.8.1

the reason why it worked in my projects was a few;

  1. we build the test binaries using go test -c and instead of executing the tests with godog in our pipelines, we execute that binary
  2. when using go modules, we ~either use go1.14 or~ run outside of the $GOPATH
  3. when using go dep, bullet 1. handles it for us, since the version is based on the dependency mgmt files

*Thread Reply:* The pinned issue: https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/253

lonnblad (https://github.com/lonnblad)
#253 Install godog with a specified version due to breaking changes.
<p>Hi</p> <p><strong>We are doing a change to godog and its dependencies that might break your project.</strong><br /> The breaking merge will happen on Monday, March, 23.</p> <p>To mitigate the change for you, we suggest that you install and depend on a specific version and not the master branch.</p> <p>To install a specific version:</p> <pre><code>go get &lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1"&gt;github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1&lt;/a&gt; </code></pre> <p>Adding <code>@v0.8.1</code> will install v0.8.1 specifically instead of master.</p> <p>If you are running within the $GOPATH, you would also need to set <code>GO111MODULE=on</code>, docker example:</p> <pre><code>GO111MODULE=on go get &lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1"&gt;github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1&lt;/a&gt; </code></pre> <p><strong>If you want to help verify the release candidate for <code>v0.9.0</code></strong><br /> Tag <code>v0.9.0-rc1</code> can be used to try the coming <code>v0.9.0</code> release, the release documentation can be found <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/v0.9.0-rc1/release-notes/v0.9.0.md">here</a>.</p> <p>BR<br /> The godog maintainers</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog">cucumber/godog</a>

slashfoo (https://github.com/slashfoo)
#267 support a "go test" format
<p><strong>Desired feature description</strong><br /> I use :GoTest from within vim and using the plugin <a href="https://github.com/fatih/vim-go">https://github.com/fatih/vim-go</a>; like with other tools (e.g. :make command in vim), they feed from the output having a specific format to populate a list of errors and provide navigation to erroring files:linenumber combinations.</p> <p>In specific, if I run godog from within go test, it'd be ideal if it'd output lines that matched the expected from the go test command and keep my workflow intact.</p> <p>Example of failing-test output of a plain <code>go test -v</code> run:</p> <pre><code>=== RUN TestSet TestSet: main_test.go:24: got = 3; want = 9 --- FAIL: TestSet (0.00s) FAIL exit status 1 FAIL test_proj 0.038s </code></pre> <p><strong>Desired solution description</strong></p> <p>Having this in my <code>_test.go</code> file:</p> <pre><code>... var opt = godog.Options{Output: colors.Colored(os.Stdout), Strict: true, Format: "pretty"} ... func TestMain(m **testing.M) { ... for _, arg := range os.Args[1:] { if arg == "-test.v=true" { // go test transforms -v option opt.Format = "go-test-v" break } } ... status = godog.RunWithOptions("test_proj", func(s **godog.Suite) { FeatureContext(s) }, opt) ... } ... func FeatureContext(s **godog.Suite) { s.Step(`^there are (\d+) hotdogs$`, set) s.Step(`^I eat (\d+)$`, subtract) s.Step(`^there should be (\d+) remaining`, checkRemaining) // this is line:52 s.BeforeScenario(func(interface{}) { Hotdogs = 0 }) } </code></pre> <p>And when running <code>go test -v</code> see the output in the desired format, something like:</p> <pre><code>--- FAIL: TestSuite (0.00s) main_test.go:52: Expected 7 hotdogs, but there are only 6 FAIL exit status 1 FAIL test_proj 0.051s </code></pre> <p><strong>Alternatives considered</strong></p> <p>• not running with <code>godog.RunWithOptions</code> and instead using a wrapper that'd contain output in the expected format.</p> <p>An example command for generating output approximating the expected:</p> <pre><code>godog --format=cucumber | jq -r '.[] | .elements[].steps[] | select(.result.status == "failed") | " \(.keyword): \(.match.location): \(.result.error_message)"' </code></pre> <p>This is not an optimal solution as it brings me to the matching method for the step, not to the line in the <code>_test.go</code> where the godog.Suite is configured, which I could then use to navigate around in the code.</p>

lonnblad
2020-03-27 17:08:40

Hi everyone

Me and Jayson had a discussion regarding Concurrency, the existing FeatureContext and how to proceed now that we are changing the Concurrency implementation from Feature to Scenario.

These were some bullet points that we thought of.

A godog user need to be able to:

  • share state between steps within one scenario.
  • run Before and After hooks once for the full test run.
  • run Before and After hooks once for every scenario.
  • run Before and After hooks once for every step.

Based on the existing setup with FeatureContext like this example: ```func FeatureContext(s **godog.Suite){ s.BeforeSuite(func() {}) s.AfterSuite(func() {})

s.BeforeScenario(func(_ **messages.Pickle) {})
s.AfterScenario(func(_ **messages.Pickle, _ error) {})

s.BeforeStep(func(_ **messages.Pickle_PickleStep) {})
s.AfterStep(func(_ **messages.Pickle_PickleStep, _ error) {})

s.Step(`^(\-**\d+\.\d+) godogs$`, godogs)

}`` We suggest that we split theFeatureContextinto two functions,InitiateSuiteandInitiateScenario`.

  • InitiateSuite would be executed once in the beginning of the test run.
  • InitiateScenario would be executed on every scenario.

We would also alias messages.Pickle to godog.Scenario and messages.Pickle_PickleStep to godog.Step, to make the consumption more friendly and consistent for the godog users, as well as to not expose internal structures in Cucumber.

This is how the above example would look like: ```func InitiateSuite(ctx godog.SuiteContext){ ctx.BeforeSuite(func() {}) ctx.AfterSuite(func() {}) }

func InitiateScenario(ctx godog.ScenarioContext) { ctx.BeforeScenario(func(_ *godog.Scenario) {}) ctx.AfterScenario(func(_ *godog.Scenario, _ error) {})

ctx.BeforeStep(func(_ **godog.Step) {})
ctx.AfterStep(func(_ **godog.Step, _ error) {})

ctx.Step(`^(\-**\d+\.\d+) godogs$`, godogs)

}```

lonnblad
2020-06-07 06:49:38

I would like to decouple the formatters from storing the results

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 06:51:44

It depends I guess. The nice thing about the protobuf format is that you don't have to keep it in memory.

lonnblad
2020-06-07 06:52:49

not sure what you mean

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 06:54:42

One of the reasons we added the protobuf/ndjson output is that the json formatter had to keep the entire json file in memory before it could be written to file. In some use cases lots of screenshots are taken and this quickly consumes all memory -- each screenshot is kept in memory until the json formatter can write its results.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 06:55:54

If you keep a limited set of events in memory that'd be less of a problem.

lonnblad
2020-06-07 06:58:13

not sure how a protobuf formatter helps with screenshots, something will still have to keep it in memory or store it on disk

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 06:59:43

Sure. On disk yes, but disk space is less scarce then memory.

So when a screenshot is taken, and attached, an embed event is emitted. The protobuf formatter listens for this even and writes it to disk. Then the event can be garbage collected.

lonnblad
2020-06-07 07:00:15

so you basically write all protobuf to disk and then something picks it up and generates the JSON?

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 07:00:50

No, it's written to disk immediately in ndjson formatt. Protobuf can be written in binary form or ndjson.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 07:01:02

It's appending at the end of a file so pretty fast.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 07:01:54

The json formatter on the other hand captures the event and has to hold onto it until the test run is finished before the json file can be written.

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 07:06:28

Anyway, putting some events in a db isn't a bad idea.

lonnblad
2020-06-07 07:20:19

do you have a link to the proto files describing the protobuf formatter?

mpkorstanje
2020-06-07 07:23:35

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/messages

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-06-23 10:09:35

*Thread Reply:* Cucumber-Ruby specifies formatter output like this:

--format foo --output foo.txt --format bar --output bar.txt The --output option refers to the previous --format . I think this solution is awkward. In Cucumber-JVM it is like this:

--format foo:foo.txt --format bar:bar.txt The destination is what follows the colon. URL destination is possible too:

--format foo:<https://host.com/some/path>

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-06-23 10:10:02

*Thread Reply:* I don't remember what it's like in Cucumber.js.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-06-23 10:11:21

*Thread Reply:* So for godog I recommend:

• Do not implement --output • Allow --format argument to specify an optional output destination, separated by :. This can be a file path or a URL.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-06-23 10:12:35

*Thread Reply:* For URL destinations we've implemented a minimal DSL to mimic cURL, allowing HTTP headers to be set, and specify the HTTP verb.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-06-23 10:14:44

*Thread Reply:* @mpkorstanje do you know where we have docs about the curl options we implement?

*Thread Reply:* it looks like cucumber-js is the same as jvm: --format &lt;TYPE[:PATH]&gt; https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/docs/cli.md#formats

Note that options provided by `@CucumberOptions` takes precedence over the properties file and CLI arguments take precedence over all. Supported properties are: </code></pre> <p>cucumber.ansi-colors.disabled= # true or false. default: false cucumber.execution.dry-run= # true or false. default: false cucumber.execution.limit= # number of scenarios to execute (CLI only). cucumber.execution.order= # lexical, reverse, random or random:[seed] (CLI only). default: lexical cucumber.execution.strict= # true or false. default: false. cucumber.execution.wip= # true or false. default: false. cucumber.features= # command separated paths to feature files. example: path/to/example.feature, path/to/other.feature cucumber.filter.name= # regex. example: .<strong>Hello.</strong> cucumber.filter.tags= # tag expression. example: @smoke and not @slow cucumber.glue= # comma separated package names. example: com.example.glue cucumber.plugin= # comma separated plugin strings. example: pretty, json:path/to/report.json cucumber.object-factory= # object factory class name. example: com.example.MyObjectFactory cucumber.snippet-type= # underscore or camelcase. default: underscore</p> <pre><code> Each property also has an `UPPER_CASE` and `snake_case` variant. lonnblad
2020-07-01 23:02:10

*Thread Reply:* the run command is basically to replace the standard godog command now

so instead of executing: &gt; godog -f progress features, you would execute: &gt; godog run -f progress features

the same for build, instead of now executing &gt; godog -o godog.test, you would execute &gt; godog build -o godog.test

the idea is both to split those two functions into sub-comands, but also to create a structure that would allow to easier add more sub-commands in the future, like if we would want to add godog fmt

Gem
2020-07-02 10:44:56

*Thread Reply:* I worry about introducing this as it’s starting to deviate from the rest of the implementations and that’s not something we want to do. :(

lonnblad
2020-07-02 22:12:46

*Thread Reply:* @Aslak Hellesøy @Vincent Pretre and @mpkorstanje

What do you think about this change since as to Jayson’s good comment, this would deviate from the other implementations?

Not sure if you need more context, but the short one: To execute godog now, you simply run godog, depending on the flags you use, it will either run the tests, build a test runner (--output), show version information or the help information.

My proposal is to add subcommands for help, version,, run and build, instead of using flags.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-10-21 13:16:13

@lonnblad I appreciate the effort here, but a CoC is something that we need to agree on as a team. We went through a process of creating a CoC for the entire Cucumber organisation a few years ago. The result is here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Having a different CoC is just confusing, so I ask you kindly to remove the one you added and link to the official one instead.

Many thanks /cc @matt-SmartBear @Jo Laing

CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
<pre><code># Cucumber Community Code of Conduct Cucumber is used and developed by people from all over the world who have a diverse set of skills, personalities and experiences. This diversity is wonderful, and we are committed to ensuring that the Cucumber community is a safe, enjoyable and thriving environment for everyone. As a community, we expect any participant to act according to the following ground rules. They ensure that everyone within the community is clear about the behaviour that is expected of them, and that newcomers know what kind of environment they can expect to find. ## Enforcing this code of conduct If you experience or observe a violation of this code of conduct, or have any other concerns, please contact [the moderators](#who-are-the-moderators) at [mods@cucumber.io](&lt;mailto:mods@cucumber.io&gt;). We are here to help you. Your reports will be taken seriously, treated in confidence and will not be dismissed or argued with. As a member of the community, you are also encouraged to help others act according to the following principles. ## Guiding principles ** ****We are welcoming****. We believe that a diverse community is stronger, more vibrant and has more potential contributors and more sources for ideas. We aim for more diversity. We strive to welcome people of all backgrounds, identities, and levels of experience. This includes, but is not limited to members of any race, ethnicity, culture, national origin, colour, immigration status, social and economic class, educational level, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, age, size, family status, political belief, religion, and mental and physical ability. ** ****We are kind****. We are warm, courteous, patient, respectful and encouraging. Disagreements, both social and technical, happen all the time and Cucumber is no exception. These differences are where we can learn the most — if everyone thought the same all the time life would be boring! We’re respectful of other people’s opinions, experience, their skills, their commitments and their efforts. We make an effort to be compassionate towards one another, to assume good intention of others, and to seek to understand first before seeking to be understood. ** ****We are tolerant****. A diverse group of people has a diverse set of boundaries about what is OK. Sometimes one of us may make a mistake, and do something that inadvertently causes offence. When we observe this happen, we try to give the offender feedback quickly, clearly and constructively. We try to offer them the opportunity to maintain their dignity in the situation, to learn from and rectify their mistake. ** ****We do not tolerate unpleasant behaviour****. If someone repeatedly or deliberately acts in an offensive way, we will take decisive action to prevent any further harm. ## What is not OK This isn’t an exhaustive list of things that you can’t do. Rather, take it in the spirit in which it’s intended - a guide to make all of our daily interactions more straightforward and enriching. ** Aggressive behaviour, whether in words or actions, whether overt or passive, is not OK. ** In other words: don’t be mean, rude, demeaning, condescending or demanding. ** Don’t discriminate against anyone. ** Don’t shame people for their mistakes or inexperience. ** Don’t harass people, sexually or otherwise. If someone has asked you to stop doing whatever you're doing - or if you notice they don't like what you're doing - stop and apologize, even if it seems unreasonable to you. Then remember, they are not under any obligation to accept your apology or interact with you in the future. Harassment includes comments or questions related to personal attributes such as (but not limited to) age, body size, culture, ethnicity, gender expression, gender identity, level of experience, nationality, personal ability or disability, physical appearance, physical or mental difference, race, religion, set of skills, sexual orientation, socio-economic status, and subculture. Harassment also includes sexual images in public spaces, deliberate intimidation, stalking, following, harassing photography or recording, inappropriate physical contact, and unwelcome sexual attention. ** On GitHub, Gitter, Slack and other online or offline communications channels, don't use sexual/racially offensive nicknames or avatars, or other nicknames/avatars that might detract from a friendly, safe and welcoming environment for all. ** Respect that some individuals and cultures consider the casual use of profanity offensive and off-putting. ** Don’t dismiss people who react negatively to someone’s behaviour, especially your own. If someone reacts to something differently than you do, it might not be that they are overreacting. Instead, they might be responding reasonably in the context of their life experiences. Please do your best to anticipate what those sensitivities might be and respond accordingly. ** Unwelcome / non-consensual sexual advances are not okay. ** Derailing, tone arguments and otherwise playing on people’s desires to be nice are not welcome. ** When critiquing other people’s work or ideas, avoid ad hominem or personal attacks. ** Likewise any spamming, trolling, flaming, baiting or other attention-stealing behaviour is not welcome. ** Sponsors of Cucumber events are also subject to this Code of Conduct. In particular, sponsors are required to not use sexualized images, activities, or other material which is in violation of this Code of Conduct. ## Who do these rules apply to? These rules apply to anyone involved in the Cucumber community, including but not limited to the founders and staff of Cucumber Limited, presenters, organisers and attendees at Cucumber events, maintainers and contributors of open source projects, and community members engaged in discussions on issue trackers, mailing lists or chat rooms. ## Where does this apply? The rules listed above apply to all official Cucumber venues; including the CukeUp conferences, public training courses, official Slack chat channels; GitHub repositories under cucumber, cucumber-ltd, and the &lt;a href="mailto:cukes@googlegroups.com"&gt;cukes@googlegroups.com&lt;/a&gt; community mailing list. ## Consequences If someone engages in any behaviour violating this Code of Conduct, [the moderators](#who-are-the-moderators) may take any action they deem appropriate, including warning the offender in private or in public, expulsion from the community, exclusion from any interaction and loss of all rights in this community. Decisions about consequences of violations of this Code of Conduct are made by [the moderators](#who-are-the-moderators) and will not necessarily be discussed with the person responsible for the violation. ## Questions or Feedback If you have any questions or feedback on this Code of Conduct, [we’re happy to hear from you](&lt;mailto:mods@cucumber.io&gt;). ## Who are the moderators? The current moderators of the Cucumber community are: ** Matt Wynne ** Aslak Hellesøy ** Tracey S. Rosenberg ** Jo Laing You can contact us by email at [mods@cucumber.io](&lt;mailto:mods@cucumber.io&gt;). ## References / inspiration We’re grateful to these references for providing us with ideas and inspiration for this document: ** &lt;http://adainitiative.org/2014/02/18/howto-design-a-code-of-conduct-for-your-community/&gt; ** &lt;https://www.rust-lang.org/conduct.html&gt; ** &lt;https://www.djangoproject.com/conduct/&gt; ** &lt;http://hood.ie/code-of-conduct/&gt; ** &lt;https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/blob/master/CODEOFCONDUCT.md&gt; </code></pre>

Hi everyone, version v0.11.0 is now out. https://github.com/cucumber/godog/releases/tag/v0.11.0

This release includes some bugfixes and internal restructure of the codebase, but most notably;

  • godog now supports writing output to a file with --format cucumber:report.json.
  • godog now supports sub commands like godog run and godog build.

If you have any questions or find any issues, just reach out! 🙂

#370 ScenarioContext.AfterStep not invoked after a failed case
<p><strong>What version of godog are you using?</strong></p> <p>Godog version is: v0.11.0</p> <p><strong>What version of Go are you using?</strong></p> <p>go version go1.15.1 darwin/amd64</p> <p><strong>What did you do?</strong></p> <p>I enabled the hooks BeforeStep and AfterStep on godog.ScenarioContext to output som logs after each step, and it worked just fine, until one step failed. After the step failed the BeforeStep was invoked but not the AfterStep.</p> <p><strong>What did you expect to see?</strong></p> <p>Either both the AfterStep and BeforeStep is invoked on following steps after a failed step or both AfterStep and BeforeStep is <strong>not</strong> invoked after a failed step.</p> <p><strong>What did you see instead?</strong></p> <p>BeforeStep was invoked for every step after a failed step, but not the AfterStep.</p>

mpkorstanje
2021-01-26 05:37:12

*Thread Reply:* Seems to make sense. I would expect invoke around semantics.

So if a before step hook is invoked, the after step is always also invoked. If the before step hook is not invoked (because the step was skipped) the after step hook is also not invoked.

lonnblad
2021-01-26 05:49:05

*Thread Reply:* yep, I agree

lonnblad
2021-01-26 05:49:27

*Thread Reply:* what do you think about the question if they should be invoked at all for skipped steps?

Levi Noecker
2021-01-26 06:11:17

*Thread Reply:* I would vote to still invoke before/after steps, and leave it to the developer to check

✅ Frederic G. MARAND
mpkorstanje
2021-01-26 06:12:51

*Thread Reply:* Since the steps aren't executed, I'd say not invoked.

lonnblad
2021-01-27 03:00:09

*Thread Reply:* I’m a bit unsure, it makes sense to not run them since we are not executing the step itself, but at the same time, I don’t know what other people are using these hooks for.

An example from the company I work for, we use the hooks to create/finish spans for Distributed Tracing and we don’t don’t need the spans to be created when the steps are skipped.

If we would make it so that developers would have to check themselves, we need to think about the API and the flow as well, like what information would they need? Some form of status flag or the previous error?

Hsu Ronald
2021-05-23 19:00:00

Hsu Ronald
2021-05-23 22:57:41

Hi, our company has introduced godog and the size is getting bigger, however, we’re seeking for a way to help data passing and initialization etc. Context in Steps func would help this a lot, wondering any quick feedback on the current status of this enhancement? https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/360

if we have consensus on the proposal but just need some more development resource, I could help

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/360|#360 Adding context to steps>
<p><strong>Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.</strong><br /> We want to generate a library with some common steps. For example, a step that sends a REST request, a step that checks the status code, a step that validates the response, and a step that checks a HTTP header from the response. In this way, we could reuse some common steps.<br /> However, godog only passes the regex parameters as arguments. We could use a <code>struct</code> and create methods for that type. But we wouldn't get reusable steps in any scenario.</p> <p><strong>Describe the solution you'd like</strong><br /> I'd like that each scenario creates a <code>context.Context</code> instance (or custom context) and the context is passed as first argument in each step function. Instead of:</p> <pre><code>func thereAreGodogs(available int) error { </code></pre> <p>we would have:</p> <pre><code>func thereAreGodogs(context.Context ctx, available int) error { </code></pre> <p>Note that <code>context.Context</code> is immutable. So we would need to create a map to store all context changes related to godog, to return the context to chain the context for the next step, or to use a custom context type.</p> <p><strong>Describe alternatives you've considered</strong><br /> We could use InitializeScenario for this purpose but it would require a lot of repetitive code for each step:</p> <pre><code>func InitializeScenario(ctx **godog.ScenarioContext) { var stepCtx godog.Context ctx.Step(`^there are (\d+) godogs$`, func(available int) { thereAreGodogs(stepCtx, available) }) ... } </code></pre> <p><strong>Additional context</strong><br /> See <a href="https://github.com/go-bdd/gobdd">GoBDD</a> that follows this approach. See also the <a href="https://go-bdd.github.io/gobdd/">motivations to write an alternative to Godog</a> which I consider to be very good feedback for possible improvements in Godog.</p>
Labels
⚡ enhancement

12
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog">cucumber/godog</a>
matt-SmartBear
2021-06-23 08:24:43

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-06-17 14:28:42

*Thread Reply:* @Eddie Knight I'm not sure where exactly you're getting errors, but this might be relevant: In the old protobuf implementation of messages, unassigned/empty primitive/array fields would always have a default value, even if you didn't set it. At least after deserialisation, but maybe also after direct initialisation of a message object (not entirely sure).

With the new implementation, this isn't the case, at least not for the Go implementation (yet). So it could be that you're trying to read a message field that previously had a default value, but doesn't anymore.

This could be the cause of the nil pointer dereferences you're seeing.

👀 Eddie Knight
Eddie Knight
2021-06-17 14:30:27

*Thread Reply:* That is a very logical assessment. 🙇

Unfortunately I'm not familiar enough with the godog codebase to quickly find where that might be happening. I'll aim to take another look tomorrow 👍

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-06-17 14:30:37

*Thread Reply:* Maybe the Gherkin parser produces messages that are missing values for some fields you were expecting to be set.

Gem
2021-07-08 11:56:19

I wish I had the time to commit to our go version of cucumber more. I haven't read through all the backlog, but as far as "cucumber-go" or the future version of whatever we call things moving forward here are some things that I'd feel are important to include:

  1. A clean and well named interface of methods and functions for end users to utilize when writing step defs/helper methods. a. In some cases I would imagine this would be public facing aliases for internal names that we use. I don't want users to be confused by our exposing our implementation. Aka, I'd like to have user facing hooks into a Scenario instead of a Pickle.
  2. An interface that allows users to create their own formatters. b. We're already struggling with maintainer time so doing what we can to enable the community to extend the project sounds great. c. Following on a. we also don't want to try to throw learning tool XYZ and follow its changelog just so that we can maintain a formatter
  3. A foundational code base that can run either synchronously or in parallel. I don't recall all the details from godog's history but I do know there were some cases and changes that were bound by a particular model.
  4. Allowing for specification of non-standard feature directories. I don't recall if this is already in godog, but I think I may have seen an issue about it when going through them around the time of the community event. In addition to that, one of the goals awhile back was to bring the project's features in line with the other projects. I'm not sure if the other language implementations have this, but I'd like there to be a concrete consensus around whether or not this project will allow for one-off/language specific features to be added or not.

Personally I'd like to say no to custom features to try to keep things more consistent across the implementations. Is this a worthwhile endeavor? Are the other implementations trying to do this as well?

mpkorstanje
2021-07-09 12:23:17

*Thread Reply:* Mmh.

From the Cucumber side there are a few reasons for the mono repo:

• Developing and testing multiple language implementations of various components (e.g. gherkin.) • Integration testing of said components. Until recently we used to have mirror repos but they add a non trivial amount of complexity to an already complex build system.

Now that Go also supports mono we lost the primary reason to keep those around.

So might be good to look into the details.

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/406|#406 WANTED: More regular maintainers :wrench::woman-raising-hand::man-raising-hand::skin-tone-5::raising_hand::skin-tone-3: >
<p>Since Cucumber adopted this project, the bulk of the maintenance effort has fallen to just <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/graphs/contributors">one or two individuals</a>.</p> <p>While we're super-grateful to those individuals, this situation puts too much pressure on those individuals and is unsustainable. Right now, with those people busy with other stuff, pull requests and issues are starting to pile up. Thanks to <a href="https://github.com/vearutop">@vearutop</a> who's already started to <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/commit/9a335aed221fadf59b68323742f2189f4a5d782b">step in and help</a>. 🙏:skin<em>tone</em>2:</p> <p>It's clear from the number of GitHub stars that lots of people are using this project. if somebody would like to review a small change, please consider this PR of zero lines https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/407 😄

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/407|#407 Merge v0.11.0 release back to main to remove version lag>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>This PR merges <code>v0.11.0</code> back to <code>main</code> to avoid semantic version lag.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>Currently if you <code>go get</code> latest <code>main</code> commit you would receive it as <code>v0.10.1-**</code> pseudo version.<br /> This happens because <code>v0.11.0</code> is not tagged in <code>main</code>, but rather is tagged in its own branch that is 1 commit ahead (and many commits behind <code>main</code>). Because of this Go considers latest <code>main</code> as semantically earlier than <code>v0.11.0</code> and can not upgrade.</p> <pre><code>go get &lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog@3de6fb09f3e678aa7d2e3602b22a77a12b2220ce"&gt;github.com/cucumber/godog@3de6fb09f3e678aa7d2e3602b22a77a12b2220ce&lt;/a&gt; go: downloading &lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog"&gt;github.com/cucumber/godog&lt;/a&gt; v0.10.1-0.20210713061448-3de6fb09f3e6 </code></pre> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour) • Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)</p> <p><strong>Note to other contributors</strong></p> <p>No notes.</p> <p><strong>Update required of <a href="http://cucumber.io/docs**|cucumber.io/docs**">http://cucumber.io/docs</strong>|cucumber.io/docs**</a></p> <p>No updates.</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ My code follows the code style of this project. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☐ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☑︎ All new and existing tests passed.</p>

hello folks, please check https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/409 when you have some time, this is an explorative draft to streamline hooks and steps in backwards compatible manner

if this approach seems good I'll finish the PR with more details and get it done before v0.12.0

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/409|#409 Add new contextualized API for hooks and steps>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>This PR introduces new API for hooks and steps that includes context and errors.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>In order to grant more control to test suite user, we can upgrade the API for hooks and steps.<br /> This PR implements new API suggested in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/360#issuecomment-882849699">#360 (comment)</a>.</p> <pre><code>type ScenarioContext struct { suite **suite } // StepContext allows registering step hooks. type StepContext struct { suite **suite } // Before registers a hook to invoke before scenario. func (ctx ScenarioContext) Before(h BeforeScenarioHook) { ctx.suite.beforeScenarioHandlers = append(ctx.suite.beforeScenarioHandlers, h) } // BeforeScenarioHook defines a hook before scenario. type BeforeScenarioHook func(ctx context.Context, sc **Scenario) (context.Context, error) // After registers a hook to invoke after scenario. func (ctx ScenarioContext) After(h AfterScenarioHook) { ctx.suite.afterScenarioHandlers = append(ctx.suite.afterScenarioHandlers, h) } // AfterScenarioHook defines a hook after scenario. type AfterScenarioHook func(ctx context.Context, sc **Scenario, err error) (context.Context, error) // StepContext exposes StepContext of a scenario. func (ctx **ScenarioContext) StepContext() StepContext { return StepContext{suite: ctx.suite} } // Before registers a hook to invoke before step. func (ctx StepContext) Before(h BeforeStepHook) { ctx.suite.beforeStepHandlers = append(ctx.suite.beforeStepHandlers, h) } // BeforeStepHook defines a hook before step. type BeforeStepHook func(ctx context.Context, st **Step) (context.Context, error) // After registers a hook to invoke after step. func (ctx StepContext) After(h AfterStepHook) { ctx.suite.afterStepHandlers = append(ctx.suite.afterStepHandlers, h) } // AfterStepHook defines a hook after step. type AfterStepHook func(ctx context.Context, st **Step, err error) (context.Context, error) </code></pre> <p>Original API is left for backwards compatibility with deprecation comments.</p> <p>Step definitions now optionally support having <code>ctx context.Context</code> as a first argument.</p> <p>Step definition may have one of the following returns processed with help of reflection:</p> <p>• empty (nothing returned) • <code>context.Context</code> - newly added • <code>error</code> • <code>(context.Context, error)</code> - newly added</p> <pre><code>func thereAreGodogs(context.Context ctx, available int) (context.Context, error) { </code></pre> <p>The context is chained though all hooks and steps allowing pass state of earlier actions to later ones.</p> <p>Resolves <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/360">#360</a>.<br /> Resolves <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/88">#88</a>.<br /> Resolves <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/175">#175</a> with ability to inject Scenario specific data to context and read it back from Step hook.<br /> Resolves <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/397">#397</a>.</p> <p>I would also like to address <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/370">#370</a> and <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/378">#378</a> in scope of this PR if the general idea of this implementation is supported.</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• New feature (non-breaking change which adds new behaviour)</p> <p><strong>Note to other contributors</strong></p> <p>No note.</p> <p><strong>Update required of <a href="http://cucumber.io/docs**|cucumber.io/docs**">http://cucumber.io/docs</strong>|cucumber.io/docs**</a></p> <p>Not sure.</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ My code follows the code style of this project. ☑︎ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☑︎ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☑︎ All new and existing tests passed.</p>

matt-SmartBear
2021-07-28 10:08:11

*Thread Reply:* We're working on some release automation for the whole org (see https://github.com/cucumber/build/issues/42 for where it's being prototyped). I'd like to keep the release branch name reserved for making automated releases in the future.

<https://github.com/cucumber/build/issues/42|#42 Automate releases>
<p>This effort is almost there. We have a PR being created (e.g. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/build/pull/43">#43</a>) when you update the <code>CHANGELOG.md</code> file, adding a new numbered version header.</p> <p>There are a couple of snags, however, to do with the current solution of using a <code>VERSION</code> file to represent the version to be released / last released.</p> <p>• In <code>pre-release.yaml</code>, read the current release version from the git tags instead. This will mean we don't need to make a new commit in the release PR, and so we don't need to worry about GPG signing that commit. In fact we can rebase rather than squash since the <code>main</code> branch has a rule to enforce linear history as well as signed commits. That will make the release PR nicer to review. • in <code>release.yaml</code>, just read the version to be released from <code>changelog latest</code>.</p> <p>TODO:</p> <p>☐ re-enable signed commits check for release branch</p>

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/389|#389 Update cucumber/common module references to use paths instead of subrepos>
<p>We have an initiative (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common/issues/1550">cucumber/common#1550</a>) to remove some technical debt in the cucumber/common repo around publishing read-only subrepos from the monorepo. We'd like to remove/archive these read-only repos altogether, and the scripts that copy code into them.</p> <p>As part of this, we need to update godog to reference the common modules (gherkin etc) via a path within the common repo, rather than the subrepo. See <a href="https://github.com/aurelien-reeves">@aurelien-reeves</a>'s comment <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common/issues/1550#issuecomment-844766751">here</a>.</p> <p>I'm not all that familiar with the go ecosystem, but I can probably figure out a PR for this.</p> <p>What I'm not sure is about the deployment process. If we make a release of godog with the new module paths, will end users have to upgrade if we then archive the subrepos?</p>

*Thread Reply:* as I understood gobdd tries to improve on blackbox problem of godog cli, when it is used as godog run and there is not enough control on execution because godog cli does magical things under the hood

but I think most of those issues are gone if godog is used explicitly as a library with go test runner (as described in https://github.com/cucumber/godog#running-godog-with-go-test), with these flows godog suite is not very different from regular go tests and can easily benefit from standard tooling for debugging, code coverage, code analysis and so on

maybe we should encourage use of go test more

Aurélien Reeves
2021-12-15 01:15:43

Hello go developers 🙂

There is a renovate PR on the monorepo which is failing: https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1826

I guess this is due to the version of go: at the moment we are supporting go 1.13. gomega, which is the dependency updated in the PR, now supports go >= 1.16.

Go 1.16 is pretty recent, I think we may consider sticking the gomega dependency to the previous version to keep the support for go 1.13. But as I am not a go developer, I may be wrong. What do you think?

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1826|#1826 Update module github.com/onsi/gomega to v1.17.0>

matt-SmartBear
2022-01-24 12:47:34

Folks, I've been pairing with @Arianna Cooper today, and we're trying to write a test for https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/383 and we could do with some Go help.

We figured out how to run the cobra command from a test, but we're stuck on the fact that the command calls os.Exit(0) which causes the test runner to show: panic unexpected call to os.Exit(0) during test

We've tried some googling, but we're not what we should do to get past this. How can we handle expected calls to os.Exit during the test without the Go process thinking it actually needs to exit? Do we need to somehow pass in a fake os into the command? Is there another way to signal to cobra that we want to exit, without actually calling the os.Exit method?

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/383|#383 Incorrect project structure gives an unhelpful error message>
<p>Please answer these questions before submitting a bug report.</p> <p><strong>What version of godog are you using?</strong></p> <pre><code>0.11.0 </code></pre> <p><strong>What version of Go are you using?</strong></p> <pre><code>1.16.2 </code></pre> <p><strong>What did you do?</strong></p> <p>Created a new project with the following structure,</p> <pre><code>|-- features | `-- health.feature |-- main.go |-- Dockerfile |-- go.mod `-- go.sum </code></pre> <p>My <code>main.go</code>,</p> <pre><code>package main import "&lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog"&gt;github.com/cucumber/godog&lt;/a&gt;" func InitializeScenario(ctx **godog.ScenarioContext) { } </code></pre> <p>I wanted to confirm that my <code>Dockerfile</code> was correctly working and running this minimal example with <code>godog</code>. But it failed, I then tried running it with my local copy of <code>godog</code>, but that failed as well.</p> <p>After doing the following change it worked,</p> <pre><code>$ mv main.go main_test.go </code></pre> <p><strong>What did you expect to see?</strong></p> <p>A more informative error message on why <code>godog</code> failed with my minimal example.</p> <p><strong>What did you see instead?</strong></p> <pre><code>$ godog failed to compile testmain package: exit status 1 - output: compile: -importcfg: open /tmp/go-build1250231118/b001/importcfg.link: no such file or directory </code></pre>

*Thread Reply:* I've been a bit all over the place with work stuff and whatnot, but here's a PR that should address things. 🙂 There's definitely more refactoring that I'd seen/like to do too.

https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/454

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/454|#454 Change cmd setup to bubble up errors over exiting>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>Based on some conversations around testing due to <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/383">#383</a>, I've done some refactoring of the cobra command section of the code to return errors to the caller and let cobra bubble the error up to the top level call to <code>Execute</code>.</p> <p><strong>Motivation &amp; context</strong></p> <p>This change should allow the functions to be more easily testable instead of requiring potentially complicated test setup due to <code>os.Exit()</code> being called by the SUT.</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring/debt (improvement to code design or tooling without changing behaviour)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I have read the &lt;../CONTRIBUTING.md|<strong>CONTRIBUTING</strong>&gt; document. ☐ My change needed additional tests ☐ I have added tests to cover my changes. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly. ☑︎ I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p>

Gem
2022-01-26 08:32:17

*Thread Reply:* Hey @paulaolmedo! Welcome!

I wasn't a part of the initial creation of godog, but I'd suspect that there are probably at least a couple reasons.

  1. In godog the step definition code is a simple mapping between Gherkin and a particular function ctx.Step(^there are (\d+) godogs$, thereAreGodogs). I've got an old example I put together for a friend here as an additional example of step mapping.
  2. In a broader sense, technically the Gherkin keywords only matter to the reader of a feature file. There's no requirement that a Given step has to be at the beginning for instance. Absolutely happy to chat more and see if this is something that makes sense to investigate more though! I'm curious if you'd be able to expand more on what is driving this particular want?

Also, thanks @Jo Laing for looping us in. 🙂

👍:skin_tone_2: Jo Laing

Aurélien Reeves
2022-07-21 01:04:19

Hey go developers 🙂

What are the good practices regarding the go directive in go.mod files? Is it to keep it "low" to improve compatibility like we do now using go 1.13? Or to keep it aligned with go version, thus we would have to use go 1.18?

I am asking this because of renovate PRs which suggest the later (messages, tag-expressions, cucumber-expressions)

I see that godog is using go 1.16. Maybe we could at least align with that one?

Aurélien Reeves
2022-07-21 04:46:46

*Thread Reply:* From what I can read in the documentation:

> The go directive in a go.mod file indicates the version of the language used by that module. If the go directive for a module specifies a version newer than the toolchain in use, the go command will attempt to build the packages regardless, and will note the mismatch only if that build fails. So, with that in mind, I would suggest to simply stick to the latest version of go in go.mod files, and maybe keeping a CI with a previous version of go (but not too old)

Any objection?

Brian Hnat
2022-07-21 07:39:15

*Thread Reply:* I'd support sticking with the latest version.

Aurélien Reeves
2022-07-22 01:07:12

*Thread Reply:* Done

Thanks @Brian Hnat 🙂

vearutop
2022-07-25 01:39:13

*Thread Reply:* there is a minor caveat with sticking to latest version, iirc go mod tidy would fail if version of go is lower than the one in go.mod

but on the positive side, go1.17 introduced a slightly updated format of go.mod that lists transitive deps more explicitly and improves go mod download performance by lazy loading

vearutop
2022-11-30 03:17:24

*Thread Reply:* godog cli is deprecated in favor of go test due to extra complexity caused by go build replication that godog cli relies on

I think go test will work properly for your case

https://github.com/cucumber/godog/discussions/478

#478 Deprecation of `godog` CLI
<p>Historically <code>godog</code> started as a command-line tool that you can run in your project and it would parse your code and build test executor. This seems convenient at first, but comes with limitations.</p> <p>Whenever you need something more than running tests (build tags, debugger, test coverage, etc...) you may find lack of control or difficult configuration. This comes from an unfortunate fact that <code>godog</code> CLI takes ownership of some responsibilities that are usually carried out by <code>go</code> tools, those features are rich and it is not feasible to keep up parity.</p> <p>It is possible (and recommended) to run <code>godog</code> feature tests as <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog#subtests-of-testingt">subtests of <code>**testing.T</code></a>, this mode of operation aims to deliver same functionality as <code>godog run</code> with standard <code>go test</code> (and therefore all advanced Go features available too with IDE assistance).</p> <p>In a <a href="https://github.com/orgs/cucumber/teams/committers/discussions/7?from_comment=8#discussion-7-comment-8">recent discussion</a> there was an idea to deprecate and phase out <code>godog</code> CLI to reduce complexity and maintenance effort.</p> <p>I would like to learn from community if <code>godog</code> in CLI mode is still useful these days. Please vote and share your use cases for <code>godog run/build</code> that do not translate well into <code>go test</code> operation.</p> <p>Thank you for using <code>godog</code>! ❤️</p> <p>Relevant issues:<br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/154">#154</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/373">#373</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/325">#325</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/159">#159</a></p>

Hello. Is there an example on how to configure godog with concurrency? So, far, it seems all my scenarios are running on a single thread or there's a lock

Kirubel Adamu
2023-03-09 21:58:29

*Thread Reply:* Hi, you can either have your tests in separate directories and then run go test ./... go, by default, runs tests from separate packages concurrently - or you can create your tests by declaring t.Parallel() inside of them. this makes tests even in one test file, be run in parallel.

Marlon Gómez
2023-03-10 06:55:02

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the reply

But now that you're saying this, I wonder about this Concurrency feature. Because the features you're describing are go-native. Am I right?

Kirubel Adamu
2023-03-10 12:13:14

*Thread Reply:* Yeah. I mentioned the go-native options because there is an ongoing discussion on the deprecation of godog cli. check this. And the recommended way is using go test since you will get all the benefits that come with it such as debugging, test coverage, etc.

#478 Deprecation of `godog` CLI
<p>Historically <code>godog</code> started as a command-line tool that you can run in your project and it would parse your code and build test executor. This seems convenient at first, but comes with limitations.</p> <p>Whenever you need something more than running tests (build tags, debugger, test coverage, etc...) you may find lack of control or difficult configuration. This comes from an unfortunate fact that <code>godog</code> CLI takes ownership of some responsibilities that are usually carried out by <code>go</code> tools, those features are rich and it is not feasible to keep up parity.</p> <p>It is possible (and recommended) to run <code>godog</code> feature tests as <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog#subtests-of-testingt">subtests of <code>**testing.T</code></a>, this mode of operation aims to deliver same functionality as <code>godog run</code> with standard <code>go test</code> (and therefore all advanced Go features available too with IDE assistance).</p> <p>In a <a href="https://github.com/orgs/cucumber/teams/committers/discussions/7?from_comment=8#discussion-7-comment-8">recent discussion</a> there was an idea to deprecate and phase out <code>godog</code> CLI to reduce complexity and maintenance effort.</p> <p>I would like to learn from community if <code>godog</code> in CLI mode is still useful these days. Please vote and share your use cases for <code>godog run/build</code> that do not translate well into <code>go test</code> operation.</p> <p>Thank you for using <code>godog</code>! ❤️</p> <p>Relevant issues:<br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/154">#154</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/373">#373</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/325">#325</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/159">#159</a></p>
